intro: Gonzalagunia discolor var. danielis, commonly known as the Daniel's spurge, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Euphorbiaceae family, characterized by its milky sap and unique floral structures. The plant typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments, preferring well-drained soils and full sun exposure. Its leaves are alternate, simple, and often covered in fine hairs, while the flowers are small and clustered in cyathia, typical of the Euphorbiaceae family. The plant is adapted to drought conditions and plays a role in local ecosystems by providing habitat and nectar for pollinators.
